text: So typically I get in at about 6.30 in the morning, I look over the Asian markets, see the moves, the S&P, the T-notes, the JGBs, and then look at the overnight news if there's anything significant, I'll note that down, and then I'll look at the opening call for my market which is the Bund, Eurostocks and basically the whole German curve before I go into my technical scenarios and jotting them down before the market's open at And then generally I watch the markets for the first hour, just to get a feel for how they're auctioning. And then my core hours are probably from 8 to about 10.30. For me personally it's very important, it gets me in the right frame of mind at the beginning of the day because I find if it's disjointed and unorganized then I waste a lot of energy trying to get into the rhythm and focus and it ensures that I get done what I need to get done to access my edge. And then also it's a point of reference I think. when you look back over your day in your end-of-day debrief. I think deliberate practice is everything for the discretionary trader because it's a skill set that you have to develop. It's more of an art than a science, I believe. And you have to work on the individual skills that make up your edge as a trader, whether it be order flow, technical patterns, different execution techniques for different conditions. And the only way to cement those skill sets over time is through deliberate practice. I think when you're starting out it's important to be open-minded as the beginning trader I think if they come in with a fixed mindset or a rigid approach they might not find out what works for them personally because everyone's different and also it takes a lot of time so patience is very important. One day they might find a pattern that works and then it might not reoccur for It takes a long time to cultivate an edge that will last a long time.
